page.title: 08DRUMMER BOY STONE
page.content: A few hundred metres to the north of Blackpool Bridge can be found a large stone near the roadside with two hollows on its upper side, one containing 'iron'. Many theories exist to explain its position : it held sacrificial blood, it was a mould to hold molten iron or it marks the grave of a Drummer Boy. The second is thought to be the most reliable. The fused metallic substance in the hollow is not iron but slag produced by iron-ore working or 'smithing'. It is probable that the stone formed the base of a small hearth made of clay and stones and blown with a bellows. This early period of iron working is known as the Bloomery period and the method was very wasteful. It was not until the 17th Century that blast furnaces were introduced.
